caption: Figure 1: The MM-StyleBench dataset. (a) The distribution of different attributes in MM-StyleBench. the proposed dataset contains diverse images and text prompts with detailed attribute annotations. (b) Examples of content (top) and style (bottom) instances in MM-StyleBench.
description: This figure presents the MM-StyleBench dataset, a novel dataset for multimodal artistic stylization.  Panel (a) shows the distribution of various attributes within the dataset, highlighting its diversity in terms of content (e.g., objects, scenes, activities), style prompts (length and labels), and other visual features (e.g., element diversity, color diversity).  This panel showcases the dataset's comprehensive annotation, enabling detailed analysis and comparison of stylization models. Panel (b) provides visual examples of content and style instances from MM-StyleBench. The top row shows examples of diverse content images, while the bottom row displays the corresponding stylized images illustrating various art styles. The examples highlight the range and quality of the data included within MM-StyleBench.

caption: Figure 2: Overview of our alignment evaluation pipeline. First, (a) we sample content and style from MM-StyleBench for stylization, and construct 2AFC comparison sets by sampling from all possible candidate comparisons. (b) Human preference data is collected and filtered with two heuristic indicators, which is finally aggregated as global rankings. (c) We propose ArtCoT, which involves three art-specific phases to reduce MLLMs’ hallucinations. Finally, we calculate the correlation of rankings from MLLMs and humans as indicators of aesthetic alignment.
description: This figure illustrates the evaluation pipeline used to assess the alignment between human aesthetic preferences and the outputs of multimodal large language models (MLLMs) in artistic stylization.  The pipeline involves three main stages: (a) Data Preparation and Sampling: Content and style pairs are sampled from the MM-StyleBench dataset, and then passed through various stylizers, creating a set of stylized images. These images are then used to create paired comparisons (2AFC) for human evaluation. (b) Human Preference Modeling: Human participants provide aesthetic preferences, using 2AFC comparisons that are collected and converted to a global ranking by filtering out noisy and unreliable data. (c) MLLM Evaluation and Alignment:  ArtCoT, a novel three-stage prompting method, is applied to elicit more reliable and nuanced responses from MLLMs on the same stylized images. This involves separate prompts for content analysis, art criticism, and summarization. The resulting MLLM rankings are compared with human preferences using correlation analysis to assess the degree of aesthetic alignment.

caption: Figure 3: Fine-grained comparison of different MLLM prompting scheme. We show the spearman’s ρ𝜌\rhoitalic_ρ for per-instance alignment, grouped by representative attribute provided by MM-StyleBench. ArtCoT elicits aesthetic reasoning for all scenarios, especially for instances with long and detailed prompts.
description: Figure 3 presents a detailed analysis of how different prompting methods affect the performance of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in aesthetic evaluation.  The figure shows Spearman's rank correlation (ρ) for per-instance alignment, broken down by various attributes from the MM-StyleBench dataset.  This allows for a fine-grained comparison of the effectiveness of different prompting strategies, including the base prompt, zero-shot Chain-of-Thought (CoT), and the proposed ArtCoT method. The results demonstrate that ArtCoT significantly improves the alignment between MLLM rankings and human preferences, particularly for instances with longer and more detailed prompts. This highlights ArtCoT's ability to enhance MLLMs' aesthetic reasoning capabilities across a wide range of artistic styles and contexts.

caption: Figure 4: User Interface for Preference Annotation. We present user with the source image (top), 2AFC (middle) and style prompt (bottom). The user is required to choose the preferred one by clicking on the “left” or “right” button.
description: This figure illustrates the user interface for the preference annotation task in the MM-StyleBench dataset creation. The top part displays the original image, while the middle section presents two stylized images side-by-side for comparison in a two-alternative forced choice (2AFC) paradigm. The style prompt is shown at the bottom. Users select their preferred image by clicking either the 'left' or 'right' button. This interface facilitates human aesthetic preference ranking for evaluating the aesthetic quality of stylized images.

caption: Algorithm 1 Sample a Connected Subgraph with Uniform Degree Distribution
description: This algorithm aims to sample a connected subgraph from a complete graph, ensuring a uniform distribution of node degrees.  It starts by constructing a minimum spanning tree using Kruskal's algorithm. Then, it iteratively adds edges to this tree, prioritizing edges that minimize the degree imbalance between nodes.  The process continues until the desired number of edges is reached, resulting in a connected subgraph with a uniform distribution of node degrees. This approach is particularly useful when dealing with large graphs where exhaustive pairwise comparisons are computationally expensive, ensuring a balanced representation of nodes in the sampled subgraph.

caption: Figure 5: Examples of Stylized Image. We show two uncurated examples from different stylization results, the image order are randomized. The styles are impressionist and cubism, respectively. The results covers a wide range of stylization performance, setting a realistic and challenging task for artistic evaluation.
description: This figure showcases examples of stylized images generated using different stylization methods.  Two distinct styles, Impressionism and Cubism, are represented, each with multiple variations in artistic quality.  The randomization of image order and the inclusion of both high-quality and low-quality results highlight the diversity of stylization outcomes and the challenge of establishing objective evaluation metrics for artistic aesthetics.
